user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_get_free:
```c
size_t
MHD_pool_get_free (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
#ifdef MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE
  if ((pool->end - pool->pos) <= _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE)
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE */
  return (pool->end - pool->pos) - _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The statement mhd_assert(pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos); is an assertion check (typically a macro that may evaluate the expression or be a no-op in some builds). It is not inherently unreachable: control flow reaches this point during normal execution and the check can fail at runtime. Even if mhd_assert expands to ((void)0) under certain build configurations, that merely removes the runtime check via conditional compilation — it does not create unreachable code elsewhere. Therefore there is no instance of unreachable code here.
